Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 11:23AM carly77 wrote: Hello there, I was diagnosed a year ago in July, 2008 with Peritoneal Carcinomatosis.  When they did exploratory surgery and took a biopsy, they discovered that the cancer in my abdomen could be traced back to the breast cancer I had in 2001.  In July of 2008, I thought I had a recurrence of diverticulitis, which I had had previously and went to the emergency room.  I was kept in the hospital for 10 days, where they gave me every test and scan under the sun and had all kinds of doctors conferring about my condition.  They finally confirmed that I had cancer in the peritoneum and omentum in my abdomen.  To get to the point of my telling you this, the cancer was crowding my organs and also was crowding and blocking my ureters.  I have had stents in both ureters for almost a year now.  I had them replaced this last May.  They have to be changed every 6 months or so, or else they can get clogged.  Unless a miracle happens (such as the cancer totally disappearing, which in my case, will not really happen) I will have to have them permanently.  They can cause pain at times and if you are especially active, there is bleeding.  Also, you are prone to get urinary tract infections.  Otherwise, I am able to function normally and always use those little panty liners for protection.  Hope this doesn't scare you hearing all of this, because it is something that I have adapted to and feel that this is better than having kidney failure and going on dialysis perhaps.  I'm sorry to hear that you are going through this.  I know how you feel, and my thoughts and prayers will be with you as you continue with your treatment. Best regards, Carolyn

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 03:45AM carly77 wrote: Hi again Cheryl, in regards to a stent in your case, you have a tumor which will be treated with chemo to be able to shrink it and possibly, at some point, with surgery to remove it.  So that is entirely different to my case, which is cancer implants and caking in the peritoneum and omentum (linings in the abdomen) for which I received chemo for shrinking, but which will keep coming back.  Therefore, the stents in my case are a necessary evil.  I can see that your situation would be treated differently.  Again, I wish you the best in your ongoing treatment and hope to hear that you are having good results very soon. Regards, Carolyn
